posts.topic: Diagnosed, removed, waiting on biopsy report

posts.text:
Everyone's bladder tolerance is different. Since BCG is a  cumulative, increasing by successive instillations as you progress through treatment. So having a severe reaction now and not during the first six is not. However, some patients can not tolerate BCG at all. This is a conversation you have to have with your Uro.
As was said earlier, you can cut the dose of BCG to 50%, 33%, 25% and Dr Lamm said, all the way down to 10%.  This is another conversation to have with your doctor.
Your Uro is absolutely right not to give BCG while there is bleeding.  It is not safe!
I can feel Toby's pain    I had big reactions to BCG,(spasms, bleeding, pain) but I was lucky enough to get through 24 instillations
before that happened.

Nancy
posts.topic: Diagnosed, removed, waiting on biopsy report

posts.text:
Chelsiaann,Six years ago, when I was dx'd, I wanted to hear, "you will be cured of bladder cancer, don't worry about it, you will be fine".
Until my brother said, months later, "you will never hear a doctor say that with any cancer".  It hit me with a sledge hammer.  Of course you will not hear that, but because you have found this site, you will see so many survivors here to support you and listen to your concerns, because mentally we have all been exactly where you are right now.
It doesn't matter exactly what your  diagnosis is, we all have heard "you have bladder cancer".
Stay positive, keep learning all you can about bladder cancer and visit us often with any concerns.
We are in your corner rooting you on!

Nancy

posts.text:
Unfortunately bladder cancer does return, that is why you are having three month cystos and your Uro is keeping a watchful eye.
Find out the results of your biopsy, talk with your Uro, do as much research on this site and the web, then go for a second opinion to a Uro that only deals with Bladder Cancer.
I know it seems impossible right now (we have all been where you are) but the more you learn the better you will be able to deal with Bladder Cancer.
I am happy you found us. This website has helped all of us understand Bladder Cancer, and we will be here to help whenever you need us.

Follow Sara Anne's suggestions, and know there are people on this site that can help you with any questions or support when needed.

That is great news! 

Nancy

Welcome to our site, but sorry you have to be here.  You have the same diagnosis as I had originally. I was 62 when bladder cancer came to visit me. It is the best diagnosis you can have with bladder cancer, and sounds like they found it very early. However, you do not want to sit back and not be an advocate for your well being.
Mike is right suggesting you get a TURB and I always suggest a second opinion.
I had given up smoking 17 years before, but stats show that:

The average interval between exposure to the carcinogen and the development of bladder cancer is 17 years. The risk of developing cancer is reduced but not eliminated by stopping. Bladder cancer, like early prostate cancer, kidney cancer, and testis cancer, generally does not cause pain.

This is from Dr. Lamm, a leading doctor and researcher for bladder cancer. Dr. Lamm's website answers a lot of questions that new patients have.You can find @ www.bcgoncology.com/cancer
So, I believe bladder cancer takes years to form. Eating well is always good for you, and there has been some research suggesting broccoli is especially good for your bladder.(1 1/2 cups a week)
You will find a wealth of information here, feel free to ask ANYTHING, we have all been where you are right now.

Nancy

So happy all went well with your TURB. Take it easy a couple of days.

Nancy

Once again, Pat, you are unbelievable!

Cynthia,
I guess I was one of the "lucky?" ones. When I had blood in my urine it was a Saterday morning. So much blood I went to ER. The Dr did a sonagram, and bingo, you could see three superficial tumors.
Your right, I heard from several Medical Professionals that "if you have to get cancer this is a good one". Really???
I did go back to the ER to thank the doctor who investigated to the source of bleeding, instead of saying it must be an infection.
My brother was dx'd with bladder cancer two years earlier, but I was still shell shocked. On the other hand I had a "heads up" on what to do, and where to get info. I found this site for him,   his doctor treated him with antibiotics (three cycles) before sending him to a Urologist.He had to get a neo bladder right away.  It has been 7 years for him - he is doing fine - I went the BCG route (since it was Ta then CIS a year later and 4 years (so far) for me. (thank heavens for the three month check ups)
Thanks again to everyone who contributes to this site!

You seem to be following my Bladder Cancer (and many others on this site). I had Ta followed 9 months later with CIS. That was 2 yrs 8 months ago.
I went through 24 BCG treatments, so far so good.  However, Mike is correct - very close watch. I am still going every three months for a cysto.
We were all "new" at one time, but with all the great information on this site, you will soon be very well versed on the subject of Bladder Cancer 
The best advice I can give you is to find all the information you can and question everything. Be your own advocate,which you are on the right road, by second opinions @ the top cancer center!
I would still go to the Uro, (they should always do a urine test before BCG) the fact you have blood will  disqualify you from BCG this week, but they can also check for an infection. If you have one, they will treat it and continue the BCG as soon as you test "clear".
Glad you found us

posts.text:
Hi Pat,
I couldn't agree more with Sara Anne. I know it seems redundant to say "stick to your guns", because I never doubted you would 
My last TURB, I also did not meet the anesthetist that would be with me during the brief surgery. However, I was promised once again, my records would be read by the anesthetist before my surgery (I was told this with two previous surgeries, but still awakened very nauseous (for hours), after the surgery. My last surgery, (two years ago) after being wheeled into pre-op and aware I was not given any thing for nausea, I actually demanded to see the Chief of Anesthesia. Lucky he was available, but not a happy camper. He quickly read thur my history and ordered the meds I needed. For the first time at this hospital I did not wake up throwing up for the whole day. I am sure there is an asterik next to my name, but I bet they read my chart next time 
You are so wise not to rush into a situation you are not comfortable with.  Unfortuately, a lot of medical professionals feel they have seen everything and know all, but as a surgeon told me once - no matter how many other operations they have preformed before, this is the "first" time for you and you should expect (and demand) to be heard and hope for the best outcome.
Hang in there, Pat

Nix

Patricia and Mike covered all the bases.  I would also recommend a second opinion. At each crossroad I went for another opinion, with my Uro's blessing.
I also had Ta, Papillary non-invasive BC, and you still have to keep a close watch on your bladder.  Unfortunately, BC is one of those cancers that keep returning. Nine months after my original surgery, I had Ta Papillary and CIS. That is why we keep such a close watch.  After 24 BCG I am happy to report I am two years clean, but a close watch is still warranted.
You certainly came to the right place, everyone is so educated and so willing to help you along.
It is very good news you have Ta Papillary non-invasive BC, just keep doing your research, so you are involved in your treatment.

Gator,

I was dx'ed 9/07 with CIS Ta.  After 6 BCG and two maintenance (3 each) I was clear for the past year. I did not have any bad reaction to BCG - just "spasms" on the first day (uncomfortable) and urgency - the second day - just tired. All this says is that everyone reacts differently. There is no way of knowing how you will react to BCG. After your second opinion (which is very important) if BCG is still recommended - by all means it is worth the shot! As for surgeries - only if you have a reocurrence do you have to have a surgery - the cystos are done in th Uro's office - every three months for two years - if you remain clear - then every six months.
Right now, everything seems very overwhelming for you, but after a second opinion and lots of reading you will be able to decide what is best for you.
This is a terrific site  to ask questions and get a lot of support.
Good luck

Nix

Hi Danny,
I can't speak from experience, but my brother had a "neo" bladder four yers ago (done are Barnes St Louis) and has never looked back.  He has not had any problems so far. Good luck to you.
Nix

I certainly agree with the others.  All my tests,urine cytology, NMP22 and    the FISH have come back negative - even two weeks before I had CIS Flathead tumors removed.  The best offense is a good defense. I always like to error on the side of precaution.
Good Luck

Nix

Nix

while getting a second opinion from a Uro at Moffitt Cancer Center in Tampa, FL, a Uro told me he has had to remove bladders due to patients receiving so many rounds of BCG and the bladder shrinking so much, the bladder can only hold very small amounts of urine and life is miserable for the patient.  So from what he said, the bladder was removed not from the bladder cancer but from the BCG! Every body responds differently to BCG that is why we have to keep such a close watch with a good Uro.

I know your fear, it’s hard. After having low grade tumors removed, six months later I had one removed CIS high grade non invasive. Continued with BCG (21 instillations)
Now 10 years of clear cystos.
12 years total after the first diagnosis.
This is the site that gave me courage and information to go forward well informed.
Stay the course and know it can turn around.

Nix

I do like to be positive, but admit when I heard CIS I was terrified!
I had some great doctors that talked to me and laid out the facts of CIS and that helped a lot! After all my BCG I went to a large cancer center near me, and every three months had a scope. Nothing came back.
I did drink a lot of water to flush the bladder and still do. I also ate a lot of broccoli, I was told that helps, and of course it doesn’t hurt .
Best advice: get the best specialist you can and do as much research as you can, every step of the way.
You can do this!!! Keeping good thoughts your way

Hi Suda,
I am so sorry to hear of your husbands bladder cancer, but so happy you found this forum.
I originally had 6 BCG's and one year later had a reoccurrence diagnosed as
CIS.
So went back to BCG, in total I had 23 (including the first 6) treatments  My bladder was really messed up from all the BCG's. It took two years to clear up
from all the treatments.
I can't say I had any problems with the first 6, but everyone reacts differently.
I always advise people to get second and third opinions, with the best Bladder Cancer doctors that they can see with their insurance.
Also, put this out there on this forum, because you may be surprised how many patients live near you and can advise.
Best of luck, and please keep me informed.

Hi Annebelle,
First let my extend my sympathy at the loss of your son. That has to be so difficult.
I also smoked and lived in a steel company town, during the years that the environment wasn't in our vocabulary.
Six years ago when I was dx'd, I was told smoking is the cause of bladder cancer, however after finding this sight, I can tell you there are a lot of people that never smoked.  I quit 17 yrs. before my bladder cancer, but I am sure that was the result of smoking and environment.  Doesn't really matter, we have to deal with what is on our plate right now.
Your BCG schedule does differ from mine.  My doctor went by Dr Lamm's schedule.  Once a week for six weeks, then after three months a cysto (to ck bladder) and BCG once a wk for three weeks.  I did 24 BCG's and other people on this site did 30.
As for the genetic possibility, my brother was dx'd two years before me, but we both were previous smokers and had the same environment growing up. (he is 8 years out cancer free)
I am not a doctor, but having been on this site for 6 years, I would say you have to have a TURB to remove tumors, esp. to make sure all of the tumor has been removed and for the patient's comfort!

Nancy

posts.topic: Hit a bump in the road

posts.text:
So sorry the cancer is back.....but so happy your doctor did 6 month checks after the 5 year mark.  I, too, had CIS. Did all the BCG and maintenance and so far (keeping my fingers crossed) almost 5 years clear.  BCG is exactly the way to go. I went for a second and third opinion after I finished the first round of BCG. (6 doses)Start the BCG then go for second opinion.
Good Luck
Nancy
posts.topic: Hit a bump in the road

posts.text:
Hi Cheryl,

Dr. Sexton @ Moffitt is my doctor, and he is very respected.  I am five years out, and I am pleased with his care.
I can tell you, if you tell him your concerns he will listen and give you his opinion. He has always answered my concerns.

Normally, it is after the six week course of BCG before the next cysto.  Alan is absolutely right about the bladder needing to heal before the next cysto.  If it is inflamed the doctor really can't see much and it can be painful.  After the first 6 week dose and the cysto, then you would be on the maintenance schedule which is three doses and cysto at the three month mark.

Good luck,

Nancy

Hi Amy,
I think everyone is nervous about BCG washes the first time.  It really isn't any thing to be afraid of, in fact, I used to try to visualize my bladder fighting off the cancer. After all my treatments......it did 
Good luck, and I just know that soon you will be passing on the same comments/advice everyone is giving you!

Nancy

Great News! 


Nancy
Great News, Sara Anne!!!!

Oh that's right, I forgot about the recurrence. My recurrence was in 2007 and that was the only one (keeping fingers crossed).
I will keep you in my thoughts until the day in December when you get the good news!
You, Ann and I have traveled  this journey together, and hopefully our posts (ups and downs) have helped others.
Nancy

Hi and Welcome!
Congrats on the non-invasive. BCG effects everyone differently. Some can only do one or two treatments because their side effects are so severe, others can go all the way to 30!
It sounds like you had a horrible start plus the scare of being told of cancer, I think you are doing well.
As I am sure you have been told and have read on this forum, a second opinion is always a good idea. My Uro encouraged me to get a second opinion.
It is always good to know that everything has been gone over with different eyes and educated opinions.
We know how you feel, we have all been there.
Nancy

Hi Kimberly,
I have had many cystos and 24 BCG. During this time the catheter wasn't a problem. However, I did have a lot of pain several years ago after another surgery.  It was discovered they used the wrong size, and the nurse was not very good at inserting the tube.
I would think "whatever it takes" for you to be comfortable the better.
Good Luck,
Nancy

Hi Annie,
To me, and my experience with bladder spasms, it sure sounds like you are having spasms. Once your bladder is healed, the spasms usually stop.  There are meds that can help with them.
As for the concern of a bladder infection, why not call the doctor and ask for a urine test to check.
For the bleeding and the flakes, that usually happens 10 days to two weeks after a TURB, so that is probably what you are seeing.
Bring all your concerns to the doctor, so you can discuss with him.

Nancy

Hi Mary,
I go to Moffitt in Tampa. I can answer some of your questions, however, I would have the appointment already set, before I arrived in FL. Once your appointment is set, you can have all the records sent, then a team of doctors meet and review your case and discuss how you should move forward.  Waiting until you get here could be a problem. If anything comes up in the meantime just cancel the appointment.
I have been very satisfied with my care, but I never hesitate to get another doctor's opinion in the past. I have had four different doctors review my case in the past 5 years. I went to Barnes hospital in St Louis for one.  My doctors have been very supportive in my getting other opinions. (if they were not, I would have found another doctor).
If I can help in any way, please let me know.
Good Luck,
Nancy

Great News! You did win the lottery in bladder cancer   

I feel as if I know you during this journey. I am nine months behind you, and your check ups have given me hope. I go for my 4 1/2 yr cysto in Feb.

Yahoo,

posts.topic: Four plus years still all clear

posts.text:
I can't speak for anyone else, but once I started BCG (4 yrs ago) I haven't had a re-occurrence. Total 24 BCG's, and so far so good.  If there is another CIS re-occurrence, I don't think I can do any more, because near the end I had a lot of problems with BCG.
I did have CIS, but it was caught very early. Maybe that made a difference?
I guess every doctor and every patient is different. Did you get second opinions from other doctors?

Nancy

Here's to Pat 

Nancy

Great News  Hope the good news keeps on rolling!
Nancy

Great! Now back out to the "happy dance floor" 

Nancy

We can all sympathize with you.........we have been there, and we know EXACTLY how you feel. Try to keep your mind busy   yeah, I know, very difficult to do.

Nancy

Joey,
It did get easier during the 6 month time between cystos. At first I worried that 6 months was too long between, but during that time I actually did not dwell on the BC and put it out of my mind until right before the appointment.
Stay positive, keep good thoughts and let's keep good reports going 

Nancy

WOW, Jack - wouldn't that be great? 
As anyone would remember - 5 years ago, I was "shell shocked" and sooooo scared.
Because of this forum, and all the support and information (actually @ the time it was called "bladder cancer cafe") I learned about the cancer that is taking me on a journey. I am still nervous, because I know we have to stay vigilant with BC.
Keeping my fingers crossed for all that have a cysto in the near future!

Nancy

So sorry you have been ill and have to reschedule. Hopefully, you will be able to reschedule quickly.
Nancy

Doug,
I am so happy for you.....two years, that is GREAT! Enjoy the Holidays 
Nancy

Yahoo! Great news, Ann.    
I am in the 6 month club - three months into my first 6 month cycle. I am no longer in the BCG club, but enjoying skipping the 3 month cysto.
Nancy

Kimberly,
I too was "wigged out" when hearing the words "CIS is present". After posting on this site, and getting a lot of encouragement, I did research, second opinions,sent slides off to JH, and started BCG - 6 week course and Maintenance schedule.
Here I am, three years out being cancer free  BCG did it's job - and so far so good!
Good luck to you, and please keep positing so we know how things are going!
Nancy

Congrats Ken, Good luck on the next round of BCG.  We always like to hear good news 
Nancy

Hi Mike,
I am sorry you are having such a terrible reaction to the BCG. I can only speak for myself - but after 24 BCG treatments, and having terrible spasms for over a year, I certainly had frequency but never every 60 seconds, and never a cath.
I would suggest you get to an Infectious Disease doctor, sooner the better.  This is definately a reaction to BCG and an Ifectious Disease doctor should be able to help, or at least refer you to someone who could help.
I would also start to look for another Uro. Everyone reacts differently to BCG, but this seems extreme to me.
Nancy

Most of us have been exactly where you are right now. Never seeing the end of BCG and three month checks - it does suck! Since 2006 my life revolved around BCG and cystos! Please don't lose light of the big picture! If the BCG works you will have saved your bladder and life will return to normal.  If the BCG fails, you will have the surgery and life will return to normal. The important thing is to get rid of the cancer and keep it away, and so far you are succeeding.......congratulation 

Nancy

It is ALWAYS great to finish the 6 week course of BCG! Enjoy your time off 

Nancy
posts.topic: Done with the first 6 BCG treats!

posts.text:
Alan,
Great news! you are right about getting to the doctor asap.
I had gross hematuria  and knowing my brother was dx'd with BC two years earlier, I went straight to ER - (it was a Sat) - Uro on Monday TURB Tues. - 34 months ago.  When the ER doctor asked how long I had noticed blood, I said "what time is it? - One hour ago".
So far so good for me BCG has helped so far, since I can't take any more. I am hoping it took care of the CIS which came 9 months later.
Getting to the doctor earlier is ALWAYS the road to take 
Enjoy your good health!
I go next Friday 
Nancy

Now that is one bike ride! Coasting can be as dangerous as pumping up hill 
Glad you are OK.........
Nancy

Hi Ross,
I found this on Webcafe: blcwebcafe.org/bcg.asp

Sex

Men having this treatment can pass on BCG during sex. To protect your partner from coming into contact with BCG, you should not have sex for 48 hours after each treatment. Use a condom if you have sex at other times during the six weeks of treatment. You should also use a condom for sex for six weeks after treatment has ended. www.accv.org.au/cancer1/patients/bladder/howtreated.htm 

Hope this helps

Nancy

Bill,
I also had re-actions to BCG. In fact, it is taking me over a year to get over my last one. (24th) And I do mean last one! My Uro and I both agree that my bladder cannot tolerate any more BCG 
So first off:  I had reduced to 10% BCG on my last instillation
and  still had severe problems.  But my bladder already had so much BCG, the 10% meant nothing.
Dr. Lamm also said that he "heats" the BCG for people that can't tolerate it any other way. (My Uro and I agree, we can't even try that)
I did have Ofloxacin after my BCG.
So what do I do now that I know I can't do anymore BCG? I wait, cross my fingers and toes, and hope CIS doesn't return 
I will be three years without a re-occurrence in October  .  So if it comes back - goodbye bladder. Hopefully, the BCG already got rid of all the CIS and it won't come back!
Good Luck - the reduced BCG does help a lot of people on this website. You can go as low as 1% - all you want is for your bladder to react.
Nancy

Atta boy, Joey........I just knew everything would be good new......a big Hip, Hip Hooray!!!!


Nancy

Hi Carol
The rash is a Red Flag to me. After my 15th or 16th BCG, I had a rash on my hands and feet - it itched like crazy, however once I voided the BCG it left.  I called my EX Uro, and they said it had nothing to do with the BCG - really? That was the start of the road to more and more complications to come - through number #24 BCG. I didn't run a fever, but I wish I stopped the BCG with the rash.
I would certainly get a second opinion about continuing the BCG.
I can't speak for your particular symtoms but I thought my history might help.
Nancy

Hi Jack,
I haven't heard of stretching a bladder, because of BCG shrinking the bladder, however I have heard of bladder removal because BCG had done so much damage, and the patient was having to get up during the night 10 times:(
The bladder was cancer free, but still had to remove bladder. This does happen.
I hope this doesn't happen to your friend.

Nancy

You are right. My Internist did the "patch test" before I started BCG, because he said from that point on I would test "positive" and he thought it would be a good thing to have in my file, the "positive" was caused by the BCG.

Nancy

Very interesting, Mike. That would have certainly helped you out in the very beginning.
I am sure I would have tested fine, since I did get 24 - only the 24th was a problem.  I guess my problem is because my Uro used 100% (or what they consider 100%) for at least 18 of the doses).
We still don't know if it is OK to start out with a lesser amount.
Once a patient shows too much of a reaction, Dr Lamm did tell me that the Uro can also "heat" the BCG.

We go as low as 1%.  You can also reduce retention to 30 minutes or less.
I also sometimes give heat inactivated BCG to those who do not tolerate
live BCG.
Don Lamm, MD

Thanks for writing Dr Lamm with this question

Nancy

WOW! Great news!! Excuse me while I do a little "Happy Dance" for you, Ann 


Nix

Great news! Celebrate 



Nix

Alan,
My brother had bladder cancer two years before me.  He had to get a neo-bladder right away. So first sign of blood I was off the the emergency room (it was a Sat) and it was caught while being a papiallary  Ta. So I went the BCG route. My brother is 5 years out and a "poster boy" for the neo-bladder.


Nix

David
Merry Christmas indeed! thanks for sharing such wonderful news! Let's make 2010 another good year 


Nix

I live in the Tampa area and recently changed doctors and went to Moffitt Cancer Center. I was dx'd three yrs ago and proceeded on the BCG path. I was very pleased with my local Uro, because he treated the cancer aggressively. That being said, I had some difficulty with all the BCG (after 24 washes)
My doctor at Moffitt is Dr Wade Sexton. Since it is a teaching hospital a team reviews all your records and presents the results to you. I liked the doctors so well, I am now a patient of theirs.
I strongly agree with the others about a second opinion. Through each phase of my treatment I went for second opinions. To date I have had 4 opinions, and if need be I would go for a 5th. As stated, it is very important to learn as much as you can about BC and to be your best advocate for your treatment.
I know it seems over whelming right now, but once you have a plan in place things will settle down, and you will see a light at the end of the tunnel
Enjoy your holidays with your family.

posts.topic: SW Florida and need some advise

posts.text:
If the symptoms don't clear shortly, the Infectious Disease Dr will be able to pinpoint exactly what the problem is thru tests that most Uros don't do. Don't forget BCG is a live virus that is used as the bladder wash, and different people (and bladders) react differently to BCG.This is the speciality of the Infectious Disease doctors. My own case, the 24th instillation caused BCG induced Interstitial Cystitis, which my Uro did not treat at all when I began to have trouble (because he doesn't see these reactions as much as an Oncology Uro.)
I would let your Uro know the problems and hope he can pinpoint how to treat, if there is no improvement, then I would seek help elsewhere.
Nix

Hi,
I know Patricia would say "get to an Infectious Disease Dr." I would agre. But first, have you notified your Uro? I know with my own experience, I was doing fine with BCG - on my 23nd one, I had more reaction and a lot discomfort for 5 days, but on my 24 one, the BCG (at a reduced amount) put me over the edge.I did not run a fever but the pressure was terrible.  I am still recovering - very slowly - and it has been 6 months! 
My new Uro has already said with this reaction, I can't have any more BCG.
I would definitely contact your Uro, tell him all the symptoms, and ask him if you should see an "Infectious Disease Dr? or even recommend one for you. If he says "no, you don't need one", and you are not any better, I would find one and go, don't let this drag on like I did.
Good Luck,
Nix

Congratulations! I love the good news - keep it coming 



Nix

posts.topic: Not what I wanted to hear

posts.text:
I have written to Dr. Lamm several times, in the past, with different concerns, and as always, he has given me guidance with BCG Treatments. Hopefully, this information will be helpful you.
Below are a few excerpts from some of the past emails.

It is important to avoid any carcinogen exposure.  While epidemiologic
studies have not confirmed the carcinogenicity of artificial sweeteners, I
would recommend avoiding excess use.  Anecdotally, some patients with a
history intractable tumor recurrence report remaining tumor free after
discontinuing soft drinks.  Second hand smoke, pesticides, diesel fuel and
organic chemical exposure, as well as excessive exposure to dyes should
also be avoided.
Don Lamm, MD
Reducing BCG does not generally reduce efficacy, in fact there is evidence
it can increase it.  I would reduce your dose to less than 1/3 or so.
You can hold it for a short time as well to reduce side effects.
Don Lamm, MD
We go as low as 1%.  You can also reduce retention to 30 minutes or less.
I also sometimes give heat inactivated BCG to those who do not tolerate
live BCG.
Don Lamm, MD


Nix

Sara Anne
I don't know about the Shingles vaccine, however, last Nov. I had to get a Whooping Cough vaccine, because my we were visiting my newborn grandson. I was worried about the body'd immunity fight the cancer and the vaccine.
I asked my Internist, Uro and Dr Lamm - all said it was fine, so I did.
If you are uneasy, ask your doctors or Dr Lamm.

Nix

Good Luck, Bill.  I will keep you in my thoughts and prayers.

Nix

I have my 21 month cysto on Monday and since the back wall of my bladder was so inflamed from the BCG cystitis (front wall was clear) Uro took two biopsies - results in today CLEAN! So next cysto will be the important 24 month cysto!
With the biopsy report was a yeast infection in my bladder. I am not surprised because I was on so much antibiotics for the cystitis. I did take Probotics with the antibiotics, but not until two week into the prescription.  So I now have Fluconazole to take for four days. 



Nix

Congratulations Ann, Let's keep the GOOD NEWS coming:laugh:


Nix

I am so sorry to read of your cysto. Hopefully, the grade hasn't changed. I guess we all "Hope for the Best, prepare of the worst", but at times I think and new bladder is the best!
Good Luck, I will be thinking of you,

Nix

Now that is great news - I feel the Happy Dance coming on 
I am right behind you - I go July 20th.






Nix

I love hearing great news    Thanks for sharing it with us.  Now, I am doing the happy dance for you:laugh:  






Nix

I have already had 23 BCG Treatments. I haven't had a re-occurance in 18 months. I am hoping the BCG worked on the CIS. My Uro  said he doesn't want to do any more any more BCG because of my last reaction.  I am going to Moffitt Cancer Center (it is close to me) Aug 7th for a second  opinion and a possibility of changing doctors.
From your writing, it sounds like you are doing well after your surgery? I bet you are happy to have that behind you.
Just continue to heal, and wishing you many happy years.

Nix

OUCH:woohoo: I can't imagine how painful BCG would be with IC. I did not even know this IC existed until I did research on BCG Cystitis. What a terrible desease IC is.  I have followed the diet for three days now, and I have seen improvement. It could be the sterods however, I think it is the diet and steroids. Today I purchased Prelief - Have you tried that?
So, did you do an entire  wk course of BCG or are they trying another approach?

Thanks for the info

Best of luck to you:)

Nix

Patricia,
I did email Dr Lamm, and here is his response:

Nancy,

It sounds very much like you have BCG cystitis.  It is typical not to be
able to culture the organism.  We treat based on the temporal relationship.
I treat such patients with a fluoroquinolone such as Cipr0 500mg twice
daily.  You can also use, with perhaps more efficacy, Ofloxacin 200mg twice
a day.  We add isoniazid 300mg/day.  Treatment response is slow and you
likely will need to be on double (or triple) antibiotics for at least 3
months.  Prednisone is sometimes needed to speed the response.
It should respond, but it does take a long time.
Best regards,
Don Lamm, MD

So I took this to my Uro and I am doing all that he suggested. I know it takes a long time, I am hoping to see what other patients have done for their BCG Cystitis. I am now watching my diet as UT Patients do, because if my bladder is inflamed diet would help make a difference?
I am improving in baby steps, but it is always helpful to read what others have done.

Nix

Nix

1. Know that Superfical Bladder Cancer is not minor because of the word Superfical.
2. Know that BC runs in my family - my brother was Dx'd two years before me.  He has a neo-bladder because by the time he was Dx'd  it was stage 4 CIS. Because of his history, the first day I saw blood in my urine I RAN to the doctor - so after lots of BCG, so far, I have my own bladder.
3. Know what BCG Cystitis is and find a doctor that listens to you when you explain what is going on in your body. Took the Uro 3 1/2 wks to agree I have BCG Cystitis.
4. Know that this site gives great advice and caring people respond.
posts.topic: 5 things I wish I knew at dx?

posts.text:
I am happy this is behind you and it went so well, Lady Jane:laugh:
Thank you for the update, Jack.

Nix

Does Doug have any other symptoms - frequentcy - pressure any thing that should have cleared up since the last BCG? I did not have the fever, but I did have other symptoms. BCG Cystitis does not always return a "positive" urine culture. Mine did not show a positive reading, but I sure have BCG Cystitis and because it was not pick-up, and my Uro wouldn't listen to me, I was delayed 3 1/2 weeks of treating the cystitis.
And as Patricia said, any fever this long can certainly be a problem stemming from the BCG.
Good Luck

Nix

I am not an expert on BCG by any means, but a fever for three weeks just doesn't sound right. Does his doctor know? I have only had a brief fever for a few hours, and have not read anything about carrying a fever for three weeks because of BCG. Doug, you must be worn out.

Nix

I agree 100%, Sara Anne:)

Nix

OK - I did see the Uro today, (was not going to be denied).  The first thing he said was "you look tired" - gee, you think - 16 nights getting up every hour - oh well.  He did a visual sonagram - and said it is inflammation. Sending the urine out for a culture and gave he an antibiotic, an yet another med for frequent urination (which I don't think will work until some of the inflammation goes.
So we are off to Vermont to see grandbabies, if I don't notice some improvement in a couple of days - call and he will call in another antibiotic.
Thank you to all for your support
Wishing all of you clean cystos and happy days

Nix

Thank you, I will try ditropan.  I have tried other spasm meds but they don't seem to work too well.  I have always had spasms, but during my last two maintenance rounds, I also get a LOT of pressure, which takes several days to go away. My best guess is that my bladder is so sensitive t0 BCG after 24 doses, it is very inflamed and takes time to heal. I do take advil (which does help somewhat)When I have my next Cysto July 13th, my bladder wall will still be very red.
I even had two red small areas 6 months after the last round. It is uncharted area how anyone will react with each treatment.

Nix

Hi Donna, Good luck on Monday, I will keep you in my thoughts - it is easy to worry before the cysto, and a great reason to celebrate after the all clear sign.
Nix

Thank you Diane - I guess we are all in this together! We just have to keep up on "dancing" 

Nix

Thanks, Joey
Seems we are on the same schedule.........I go for BCG next Monday, Next cysto three months from last week

Nix

Jack, I see where you also have had plenty of BCG. I will be @ 25 after this maintenance round.  I checked Dr Lamm's protocol and see as long as BCG is working after two years of 6 month maintenance - years 4,5,6 - once a yr then yrs 8,10,12 Once every two yrs.  Are you on that schedule? I don't think I have read anyone on all that - however - if it works I am good to go!
Thanks for your support - It is great the know you are not the only one on this roller coaster.

Nix

Joe
I am sooooo happy for you:) Celebrate!!!!!!

Nix

Hi Suzi - I am in Clearwater, FL. not too far from you...

Nix

My Uro was also reluctant to reduce the strength of BCG - until the 21st dose. At that one time (the last dose of the maintenance series) he reduced it to 50%. I could barely hold the BCG for more than 45 minutes. I did receive an answer to my email from Dr Lamm - he said dose could go down to !/3.
Dr Lamm's response:
"Reducing BCG does not generally reduce efficacy, in fact there is evidence
it can increase it.  I would reduce your dose to less than 1/3 or so.
You can hold it for a short time as well to reduce side effects"
Don Lamm, MD

Nix

Great news:lol: Time for the "happy dance"
Congratulations!!!

Nix

Good Luck on your next Cysto. I have had 21 BCG washes so far and each series has more side effects than the last. I have had infections and a very inflamed bladder for 2-3 months. But like you I have had clean cystos so I don't like to harp on the side effects - so far working!

Nix

Thank you to everyone:laugh: I know I gain strength by reading success stories - even though we know with BC you are never "out of the woods" - sometimes it is just good to hear that BCG does work for some/and or for some of the time. Of course, in three months I will be worried again - but the next 90 days will be fun!

Nix

Bobby,
I am happy you are getting relief. It would be a great idea to set something up with Dr Lamm. I have also emailed him several times in the past and he always answers - amazing!
Have a good trip

Nix

You do have a plan Warren, and that alone should give you some relief.Hopefully, you will have a vacation from the pain to enjoy your daughter's wedding, and cross the next bridge when the celebration is over. Hang in there.............

Nix

Pat,
Thanks for the thread.........I thought the same thing about the antibiotic, but I was also puzzled that the reaction o BCG would stop immediately, once I voided the BCG. I am printing out the info and taking to my doctor. As Warren said on another Post - My Uro might not have had a patient have the same response and so we have to be our own warriors.
As always, thanks for your wealth of information:)

Nix

I recently finished my 21st BCG. Honestly, each one is an adventure: this last time after the instillation, I took my antibiotic before leaving the office as I always do, on the way home my hands and feet and where the  catheter was inserted started itching terribly. After passing the BCG the itching stopped completely. Could the BCG have caused this? or the antibiotic - neither have done this in the past. Just wondering if any one else has had this reaction:unsure:
Anyway, Happy New Year to all who have been such a blessing to me and others on this site.  Wishing everyone a HEALTHY NEW YEAR:laugh:

Nix

Jack - I am just ahead of you, I am cancer free for 14 months, next scope is 2/7/09. I have another installation of BCG to finish my 4th maintenance - and hopefully after another clean cysto 6 months until my next BCG. Not complaining only because it is working so far.
Wishing everyone a happy HEALTHY BC "FREE" year!

Nix

That's what we like to hear - Merry Christmas

Nix

Hi Craig
I certainly don't know of a neo-bladder surgeon in your part of the country, we are almost opposite ends of the US. It sounds as if you have made your choice, and maybe someone on the forum will know a good connection.
Have you tried BCG?  BCG is effective with CIS. It is the treatment of choice.  Just something else to consider. Best of luck with whatever you decide:)

Nix

Don,
I think we have all been there - sometimes enough is enough. I my last two cystos also had red spots - he biopsed during the cysto and it was just from the BCG. I have found that if it is on my mind, better to get it done that think about it all the time.
Good Luck
Nix

Suzi, Congrats! That is ALWAYS good news for all of us to read!

Ann,
My schedule is the same as yours. I guess not everyone follows the same schedule. If I have three more clean cystos then I can move to 6 months for three years - that is fine with me!


Nix

I really don't worry about "holding" the BCG much over an hour since my second maintenance. Since I have had three maintenance, the side effects get stronger every time. As for the reduced dosage quoted from Dr Lamm  "When patients begin to have increased symptoms following BCG instillation, the dose can be reduced to 1/3, 1/10, or 1/100th as needed to prevent significant side effects with subsequent treatment. Never give BCG if symptoms from previous BCG administrations are still present, and never instill BCG if the catheterization is traumatic or bloody. Nothing is lost by postponing BCG treatment if patients have symptoms, because symptoms are evidence of continued immune stimulation. Excess BCG administration is associated with increased side effects and suppression of antitumor immune response."

Nix

Don,
I agree with you. I guess because my doctor does not have the spasms, he doesn't understand how severe they can be. However, this time I think he knows. It is the first time I had spasms straight through 17 hrs - without any relief.
Since this was number 13 with the original 6 and now third maintenance round, I am sure my bladder has become more sensitive.
thank you for interest!

Nix

Don,
I have mentioned this to my Uro in the past. He said that since I did not have any severe side effects from the full strength he would prefer to stay with that. This time I feel it was a severe reaction. Last evening and all night all I could do was walk the floor. This afternoon I am getting some relief, hopefully by tomorrow I will be back to normal.(then in five days - here we go again) I did call the Uro today and suggest we cut the strength; Hopefully, you will sail thru:cheer:
Nix

Sara
This is also "kind of" an anniversary for me also.  Two years ago, the Monday before Thanksgiving I was dx'd with Ta and had a TURB. a year ago I was dx'd with Ta CIS another TURB. One year later, 6 weeks BCG and two maintenance rounds and ready to start next maintenance on Monday - here I am also. Full of hope (13 months All Clear:) and very thankful for this forum.
Thanks to all

Nix

Claudia,
I am sure your Dad will be fine.  We have the 3 month cystos to keep tabs on our bladders and to catch anything early. (which is what your Dad is doing) Good luck and let us know how everything comes out.
Nix

posts.text:
Well, after reading Warren's response, and talking to my URO and Internist I received a DPT today, and feel confident that all will go well with the BCG and the DPT. Thank you so much Warren for your insight and Patricia for your thoughts!
We all have a lot to be thankful for this Thanksgiving, and at the top of my list is this Forum:)

Nix

posts.text:

posts.text:
Patricia,
Everything changes so fast. I was at the birth and helped care for my Granddaughter just two years ago, and this was not mentioned. If I had heard this a month ago - no problem, I was between the BCG's. Oh what we do for our wonderful grandchildren!!

Nix
posts.topic: Does DPT vaccine hurt the immune system?

posts.text:
Warren,
Thank you so much for taking time to give me an educated answer. After reading  your response (several times) I do have relief if I decide to receive the vaccine. One other fact I did not mention is I am 64 1/2 yrs young and I had a DT vaccine 2 1/2 yrs ago. I can't help to think that 6 months from now this would not be in question, since I would be that "magic" age of 65:) My PCP said I would have more of a "local" reaction because I still have antibodies in my system.
Thank you so much for your time and effort you put forth your help on this subject! Any other advice is always appreciated!!!!

Nix
posts.topic: Does DPT vaccine hurt the immune system?

posts.text:
Great news, John ..........enjoy your "time off"

Nix

OK - I am just guessing here, but maybe since they are talking about an injection (thru the blood stream) and not a "bladder wash" that the BCG vaccine should be stopped.
Does that make sense?

Nix

Sara Ann

WOW! Take a deep breath and give yourself a big hug! That is great news:)
I go Monday for my cysto and of course, I am very nervous.

Nix

Claudia,
We all have bad days, and you came to the right place. That is why we have 3 month check-ups the first two years, so our doctors can catch the sneaky BC early. Is he on BCG? If so, they will probably repeat that. Don't push the "panic button" until you have all the facts and results.  It could be a number of things that can range from an infection to irritated  spots from BCG.
Hang in there, I pulling for you:)

Nix

I am happy that is behind you and all is well.  Hopefully the BCG will work and the paths come back with no surprises:)
Nix

Ro
Let me chime in - I thought you were blonde - your hair looks so soft and shiny - I just thought you were a natural blonde - if you want to go back to red - go - life is too short not to do what we want:)

Moonerj
I have never heard of monthly treatments.  How many months will you have the BCG?
Nix

Max - Great news on your cysto! I love to hear great news - it gives all of us hope:)
It is great you go to the Derm and stay on top the skin cancer, I hope all goes smoothly.
Nix

Sara Anne
I asked my doctor the exact question last year at this time - I got the flu shot in October and had my first 6 BCG in November.  I didn't have any problems with the shot or the BCG:)

Nix

I get very tired the next day - and once I had a slight fever. Other than urgency, the symptoms leave within two days. I know everyone reacts differently but  I think it would be good to talk to your doctor and shoot off an email to Dr Lamm.

Nix

David,

I am so happy all ended well!! Enjoy your Holiday...........

Nix

Sara Anne,

I am so sorry you have to go thru this. It is hard enough to deal with Bladder Cancer and everything that goes with it! Over a year ago, when I was to start my BCG, my Uro's nurse was new.  I really liked her, however, when I heard she had never done BCG before, I told my Uro, I didn't want to hurt her feelings, but since he had several partners, I wanted one of the other nurses that had BCG experience, to administer the BCG. His reply was "she has to learn sometime" - I agreed, but she wasn't going to learn on me:) I think her feelings were hurt at first, but I didn't care and she did get over it. Now for all my maintenance I have the same nurse.  I do think experience makes a difference.  My nurse always streams the BCG slowly to help with the spasms. I still get spasms, but maybe they aren't as bad as they would be.  It is hard to stand our ground, but unless the professionals have had Bladder Cancer themselves they can't know exactly how vulnerable we feel.
Hopefully, this past one will be OK and you can ask for another nurse next time.

Nix

Ian,

A split penis - it sure sounds like a big deal to me! Makes me happy to be a girl  I dread my cystos, but you must absolutely hate yours! You should certainly go to a Uro you can communicate with.  Do you only have a choice between the two - the first one and this one? Maybe you could get another recommendation? Is there a cancer center near you? Maybe they would be better since they deal with this more frequently.
I am sorry I can't be of much help, but I too am happy you have the good news of the low grade BC.
When is your next cysto?
Good Luck,
Nix

Patrica,
Thanks for the article.

Nix

It is great to hear good new  Have a great weekend!

Nix

Good Luck on your Cysto - I know the feeling - can't wait to get it over with but at the same time "fear" the results.
Please let us know how everything goes - try to enjoy your weekend.

Nix

Susan,
I have been dealing with Bladder Cancer for only two years......so I am not and expert by any means.
Of course when I heard the word Cancer I was very upset. Since mine was Ta it was removed and I thought all is well.  I guess I thought you just took care of the cancer and moved on - nine months later CIS was removed and I felt my world turned up-side-down.  After reading everything I could and getting second and third opinions I had the 6 BCG and so far 2 maintenance rounds.  Just passed my one year clear mark.
I think in the beginning I thought I would get "you are cured" from the Uro - after understanding that just does not happen - it is a process.
The Bladder Cancer road has been a continuing journey for me, since I am type A personality, I like to get things done and move on and it will not happen with this, it just doesn't work this way.
So on days when I am scared (right before cystos) I thank God for my husband, children and grandchildren - prepare for the worst and hope for the best.
I am indeed grateful that we can  be watched closely and any bumps in the road  acted upon ASAP.
As I said before, this is a journey.

Nix
posts.topic: I need input from you all

posts.text:
I love to hear good news! Congratulations - do something special this weekend.
Are you now on 6 month cystos? - if so that is a great place to be!

Nix

Joey, Very interesting.  I also had a FISH test and it was negative - that was right before my CIS was Dx'd. Hopefully, this new process that Rosemary educated us with, will help.  I really thought CIS would show in a cytology. That is one reason why I was so floored when it was found I had CIS! My scope is 9/2 - I am taking all the information with me - I will let you know what my Uro has to say.
Nix

Rosemary,
When I go for my next "cysto" I am taking all your information for my Uro. Every Cytology I have ever had - for two years - comes back negative. Even my first one , and I had 5 Ta - and then when I had CIS dx'ed I also had a negative cytology.Altought it is great to hear negative, I want the whole story. Thanks again for the info. I really appreciate it .
Nix

Lynn, I am glad you are going to have another cysto to find out just exactly is there. Better to know, than to worry for three months.  Hopefully, it is just scar tissue or something else that is not of concern. Good luck and let us know the results.

Jon,
I have only had a little blood pass on my first day of BCG's. I am sure it is fairly common. You did the right thing to report it to the doctor.  Do they do a urine test before every BCG? Make sure they do, and if all is clear they will do the next treatment.
Nix
posts.topic: 6 days after first BCG and some blood

posts.text:
Way to go - Congratulation!!!! Go have some fun.

Nix

Susan,
I know,it took me quite a while to wrap my brain around the whole BC thing! One doctor actually said "Doctors used to say 'here comes long term money' because BC is a life long desease". Believe it or not, that actually made me feel better, because I know a lot of cancers that are swift and deadly. So, everytime I have to start BCG Maintenance, I am thankful that I don't have to do chemo (with drugs in our blood stream) and marvel that so far BCG is working . Rosemary is so right, as long as you feel you are doing all you can, it gives you a handle on the road ahead. Rosemary has helped me so much on my journey.
Just know, we are all with you - with BCG - and the good times of the all clear scopes!

Lynn,
I think we are all in the same boat - good for 2 1/2 months then start getting nervous! I try to keep busy and pray that all is well. Please let us know how everything goes...........I will be thinking of you.

Tommy, Good news. although, I am nearly two years into this, I love to read the about the clear cystos! thanks for sharing.

Nix
Congratulations Max, It is always great to hear good news
Good for you! Enjoy your time "off"!
posts.topic: Monday and then that is it!!

posts.text:
I am very interested in your BC since I am only two years into this. First I had Ta and nine months later dx CIS - flathead multi focal. Had it removed and came back no invasive CIS.  I have had 6 BCG and two maintenance (3X each) So far all clear:).
My Uro led me to believe that if another occurrence of CIS I would have to have my bladder out.
So after reading your post, I think I understood you to say you had CIS return and just had more BCG? Is that right?  Did the BC then respond to the BCG?
Thank you for any insight you could share with me.

I also have papillary - Ta and CIS.  My papillary was found in Nov 06 - I was clear for 3 Cystos then on the forth - red velvety patches were biopsied and sure enough CIS. So I would have to say, according to my history  they are independent.  Some people just get a papillary Ta once and it is removed - then nothing else comes back .  I have never had another tumor - just the red patches.  Of course, I am not happy about
the CIS, however BCG does work well on CIS and not just Ta.  I guess I am looking for a silver lining to the cloud !
Thanks for the link, Patricia.  It is a very good article that covers all the ins imfomation about BCG.

Dr Lamm does recommend cutting the dose, however my Uro said, since I have not had any bad reactions, he has been using the full strength.  So far, so good.  If I do run into any problems down the road - he will cut back.

As you know already, everybody reacts differently.  As for my Maintenance BCG, The reactions was a little more pronounced, but certainly bearable.  I have had two maintenance so far, and three clear cystos - so hands down it is worth it - so far.........
Good Luck

Great news, Slabman! Thanks for posting the results.  I had my third, and last, BCG maintenance yesterday, but I did ck to see how your cysto results were.
Are you doing the maintenance now?
Nix aka NancyS

Great news Sara Anne! I did find I had a few more side effects with maintenance, but nothing severe. Everyone is different with reactions to BCG - just cross that bridge when you get to it.
Have fun tonight - you have earned it!

Nix
posts.topic: First Poke and Peek post BCG

posts.text: I know, Susant, sent a "help me" email about the same concern yesterday, haven't heard anything yet.  I know it is hard to get everything "up and running", but I hope we can view and read the same a Webcafe.
WOW! That is a great outcome! Congrats! Thank you for posting, it gives us hope!Wishing you smooth sailing!

what was your original dx? stage? number of tumors? Thanks for any background you can share.
Nix

I have had debris in my urine during and after my maintenance BCG. I am in the middle of my second maintenance (of three)and here I go again.  My Uro does, of course, do a Urine test before every BCG, but I wonder if other people have debris floating around  for aleast 3-4 wks? Is this normal?  So far the BCG has done its job - 2 clean cystos.
thanks for any input.

Great News - keep doing what you are and don't forget to celebrate the great results!!!
NancyS

Good Luck with your cysto - I will be waiting to hear..............


Nancy

I had my third clean (cancer free) cysto today!So far - BCG is my hero! I have had 6 wks and three maintenance and now I do three more maintenance and another cysto in September.
Of course, I have a few side effects from the BCG (small fever, bladder spasms, and complete tiredness the next day, but small price to pay for a good clean cysto.
Thanks to everyone who has hung in there with me, believe me, I say a prayer everyday for all that are in the same boat with this BC.

Nancy S

Susant,
Of course it is normal to have all those feeling. Once we hear the word cancer, the fear is instant. Once I did a lot of reading and research, then I started to calm down and focus on beating this.  I think it helps to know everything you can about your new enemy - BC and be vocal with your Uro, every step of the way - that way you are in control not just the doctor! Hopefully, your Uro is open to working with you - if not find another one. There is a lot of hope out there, and this is just the place to read about the sucess in treatment for BC.
Good luck - take a deep breath and move forward.

NancyS

Gina,
For sure I would request (or demand) an antibiotic on the day of the BCG.  Any time you have a catheter there is a chance of an infection.
I can't promise it is worth it - however I can tell you so far so good for me.  I have had the initial 6 wks and two maintenance (3 wks each) so far it looks good, and this is the best proven course to follow.
So just hope for the best - Good Luck
If I can help in any way please ask!!

Nancy S

Hi Gina,
I have a urine test before each BCG and Cipro for two days after each installation. If I have an infection, we hold off on the BCG for a week until it is cleared.  Cipro will not affect the BCG. Did you receive any antibiotics on the day of BCG?

Nancy S

Slabman,
Just as Dan said, they will do a cystoscopy.  None of the doctors want to do a cystoscopy during bcg. I went for my second opinion (to Barnes St Louis) right after my doctor did a cysto after my frist 6 wks of BCG.  Then I felt four eyes are better than two!
Good luck
Nancy

David,

What great news!!!! I am so happy for you, and it gives hope to all of us.  Just stay on top of BC like you have been.  Celebrate every day!
Nancy S
posts.topic: Cystectomy Needed for Recurrences of TA, CIS Non-Invasive BLC?

posts.text:
Gina
Happy you are all most thru with the initial BCG, however, keep a close watch on your fever.  Make sure your doctor knows that you had a fever and how high.  You really don't want to ignore that.  After running low temps. (one time 101) my Uro suggested I take Tylenol every four hours on the day I receive my BCG.  Tried that the last time and it worked.  I just had a brief time (about 30 min) that I had chills.
Good luck - hang in there.
Nancy S

Slab,
My BCG are always at 10 AM - I eat breakfast - cereal and yogart - but I never have coffee on BCG day.  You may have a normal appitite on BCG days, or you may not feel like eating much.  I do drink a lot of water  after the two hours of holding the BCG. It seems the more water I drink the faster I get back to normal.  I forgot to mention, one of the side effects I have noticed since my maintenance  is being really tired the day after the treatment.

Nancy S

Sol,
I can only speak of myself, as I am not a authority on BCG - however, I am learning more and more.  During my initial 6 WKs of BCG, I had to postpone one (for a week) due to an infection.  I then completed all, have had 2 scopes and clear.  I just completed my maintenance 3 BCG) and also had to postpone the last treatment 5 days, due to another small infection and the URO wanted to be careful.  I am not sure I would have postponed except unless the URO reccommeded.  I like to get thru the treatments as scheduled.  But that is just me.  Good Luck
Nancy S

You are something else, Patricia! Thanks so much - I did read the article and I will  to store the info in my info.
This forum is sooo enlightening!

posts.text:
Gina,

We are all scared, however with time you will learn to put your worries in their place and live in between the cystos. Just learn as much as you can, ask a lot of questions and get second, third and forth opinions - if need be.  This forum has helped me so much, I am sure it will also help you.

Gordo and Craig
I don't have much bleeding, just a drop - however my Uro told me not to take Ibuprofen, since it can cause bleeding. So since my dx I have used Tylenol. I do get a fever for a few hours, but other than that so far the only problem are the spasms. I guess so far I am lucky, I have one more maintanace to go thru next Mon.
I called my Uro and he suggested I try Detrol LA. So I take one pill a   day during BCG. I don't know if it will work this time, since I am only taking it for 5 days before BCG. If it works I will let you know.
My spasms have very slowly progressed with the BCG - this last time they were more intense and lasted much longer. If this does not work, I am going to suggest a smaller dose of BCG
Thanks for the info,it is good to know we are not alone during all this treatment!

Warren
Wishing you a "speedy recovery" and congrats on the good news of "no cancer"

Nancy S

david,

I am sorry the BCG wasn't the medicine for you.  I am hoping it works forme - so far I had 6 wks clear cysto - next on on Monday - if all clear 3 wks of BCG - I guess I have to keep hoping it will help.  My Dr did say if I had any return I would have to consider having a cystectomy.  One of my 2nd (3rd?) Opinions from the Cancer hospital near me, said there are other treatments - however, I have heard BCG is the best shot. It sounds like you ave a good plan with MD Anderson. We are our best advocate for our health - Education and Follow-Thru!
Good Luck!
Nancy S

David,
I read that you had 6 wks of BCG - did you have BCG maintenance also?

Nancy S

Hi Rosemary,

How many BCG's have you had?  I know with my CIS it is a different ballgame - but I am (hopefully) having maintenance BCG if my next scope is clear.
As everyone suggested on the forum, I did go to Moffitt Cancer Center and meet a great Dr.  - He said my Uro was doing exactly what he would do - and hopefully I will continue to get clean cytos.  Of course, I am very worried right before each cysto. My last appointment to get the results of the byopsies was @ 4 PM - I thought  the time would never get pass - fortunately, it was good news - from now on I will go early in the day!
NancyS
posts.topic: Tired of Doctors and another stupid test tomorrow

posts.text: Thanks for the link - I do eat a healthy diet, but have wondered if I should take a supplement while fighting Bladder Cancer. I am sure I get the daily dose with my diet, but still pondering adding more. ???

Hi Everyone,
Brief history, 11/06 diag. with BC Ta - TURB and 6 wkds BCG.  Three clean cystos - DISH neg - forth showed velvety red and diag Ta CIS 10/07. Dr said BCG is more effective with CIS so had Intro (6 wks) BCG.  A lot more reaction this time - bladder spasams, a little bleeding, low fever - once, urine urgency  and just general overall blah! Had cysto last week - negitive! - Dr said my bladder really reacted to BCG - entire walls were  inflamed - he took 9 biopsys to be sure - all negitive.  So now I have three months to push this back in my mind and get ready for the next stressful cysto.  If all clear  I will have 3 wks of maintenance BCG.  I know (if I am lucky) BC is always there with the fear of the next cysto - it is just learning to live your life with BC and not let it take over ALL your thoughts and lives.
Thank you to everyone who has helped me so much in the past, and I am sure in the future.
And thank you to everyone who posts on the site, as it sure helps to gather information quickly when you feel desperate.  Everyone is so kind and supportive!

Hi Rosemary,

I just had my third intro to BCG (I had six wks a yr ago after Ta was found.  Now with CIS I am starting again also with maintenance in three months.  Last yr I did not have any side effects.  This time I had some bleeding and a slight fever 99.9 for a few hrs. Is this normal.  The bleeding stopped in a few hrs also.

dmartin12358,
thank you for the information - for sure I will be on the phone with the Moffitt Cancer Center tomorrow at 9AM Sharp!
thank you to everyone who took the time to write, I do not know how I would have gotten thru this weekend without all of you

thank you fearandfight for your listing. I have Moffitt cancer center on my schedule to call tomorrow morning. Do you feel it is better going thru a cancer center rather than a general Uro?
And also = thank you for your patience. I am just a little spastic right now - I really don't want to sound like a whinner.
Nancy

Wendy,
I am trying to get names of dr in my tampa area for second opinions now.  We are not real familiar with this area, haveing just moved here three yrs ago. Up to now I am pleased with my dr however, I know it is important to have more insight than one dr.
Thank you for your kindness.
Nancy

Hi Mystic

Did you have the basic 6 BCG after the first surgery?  I had Ta, but my Uro strongly suggested at least 6 treatments.  I did all six  - one a week for 6 weeks - no problem.  For 24 hrs I had urgency - but other than that I was fine.  I am a little concerned if he wants me to have three more, because from what I have read here, those seen to get a bit nasty.
This board has helped me so much - the people are great!! - We are all in the same boat

Alice,  No wonder you are second guessing yourself, Alice .  you have certainly had a "full plate" and then the insurance problems on top of everything else.  I know it sounds easy to say - just try to find the best doctor you can and if you have to travel 2 or 3 hrs - just do it.  But some circumstances hold us back.  I will tell you to keep looking until you find a doctor that you trust and of course one that will listen to you.  I wasn't thrilled with my URO, until I flew to St Louis for a second opinion, from a doctor I respect.  He was very supportive of the treatment my URO choose and that was very comforting.  Maybe, you could find a local doctor, and then pick one for a second opinion, just to give you peace of mind.  if you have to travel once for a second opinion  just to double check your doctor - it would be well worth it.
I know the next several days will go slow for you, but you will be in my prayers and thoughts.  Hopefully, everything will be fine and you can relax for a while.
posts.topic: What are the chances of a Person being wrongly Diagnosed?

posts.text:
Thank you, Patricia
There is such a wealth of information on this website.

I also was diagnosed in fall 06- Mine was Ta 2 1/2 mm all low risk.  My URo suggested BCG (six) just as procaution.  I had no side effects except the usual urgency and a little burning for a 24 hr period.  When I went for a second opinion - that URO said he would not have done BCG however since it was over and all was well - it was insurance.  Then my URO did a FISH test.  Have any of your doctors done that?  Mine came back neg - but I did not hear of it until I had it and then did some research on the FISH.
I go for my third cysto end of sept - then my doctor will decide on any more BCG.

Since my brother went to Barnes/Dr. Bullock, I have nothing but praise for the Doctor and Hospital.  My brother is celebrating 11 years with his neo bladder, he was 69 at the time of surgery.  He has not had to "self-cath" but some of the others do, it does not seem to be a problem either way.
Good luck, and you found the right site to help you, everyone is so informative and helpful.
We have all been down this road called Bladder Cancer, and there are a lot of positive outcomes.

Nancy

I am late reading this, but I might be able to help.  My brother @ age 69 had a neo bladder at Barnes, Dr. Bullock was his surgeon.  Since that time he hasn't had any problems, however, I have read some patients do have some problem.  He does not have to cath, but that does not mean your husband will not have to.
I am sure a surgeon will tell you what is best for your husband's particular case.
Good Luck, I hope this helps

I quit smoking 17 years before I had Bladder Cancer. When I was first diagnosed, 10 years ago, I found a doctor on line that I contacted, and much to my surprise, he answered many questions for me.
In his writings, he suggests that up to 17 years after smoking bladder cancer can be the result.
My brother also had bladder cancer before, he was a smoker at the time, but we also grew up in a steel town, during the 40,50,60,70,80'sLots of air and ground pollution, an city used well water at that time. No surprise there is a lot of
cancer in that town.
My brother had a neo bladder 12 years ago, is 80 yrs old and doing very well.
I caught mine very early, because of my brother, I had BCG, and I am 9 years cancer free.
My past caught up with me, but because I quit smoking I feel I had a chance at a cancer free recovery.
Good luck, congrats on not smoking, I do know how hard that can be!

Girls' Night Out

Some 40-year-old girlfriends discuss where they should meet for dinner.
Finally, they agree to meet at the Ocean View Restaurant, because the
waiters are cute and buff.

10 years later, at 50 years of age, the women once again discuss where they
should meet for dinner. Finally, they agree to meet at the Ocean View
Restaurant, because the food is very good and the wine selection is
excellent.

10 years later, at 60 years of age, the girls once again discuss where they
should meet for dinner. Finally, they agree to meet at the Ocean View
Restaurant, because they can eat there in peace and quiet, and the
restaurant has a beautiful view of the ocean.

10 years later, at 70 years of age, the women once again discuss where they
should meet for dinner. Finally, they agree to meet at the Ocean View
Restaurant, because the restaurant is wheelchair accessible, and it even
has an elevator.

10 years later, at 80 years of age, the girls once again discuss where they
should meet for dinner. Finally, they agree to meet at the Ocean View
Restaurant, because they have never been there before.

Please join me in remembering a great icon of the entertainment community.

The Pillsbury Doughboy died yesterday of a yeast infection and trauma

complications from repeated pokes in the belly.  He was 71.

Doughboy was buried in a lightly greased coffin. Dozens of celebrities

turned out to pay their respects, including Mrs. Butterworth, Hungry Jack,

the California Raisins, Betty Crocker, the Hostess Twinkies, and Captain

Crunch.  The grave site was piled high with flours.




Aunt Jemima delivered the eulogy and lovingly described Doughboy as a man who

never knew how much he was kneaded.  Doughboy rose quickly in show

business, but his later life was filled with turnovers. He was not considered

a very smart cookie, wasting much of his dough on half-baked schemes.

Despite being a little flaky at times, he still was a crusty old man

and was considered a positive roll model for millions.




Doughboy is survived by his wife Play Dough, three children: John Dough, Jane

Dough and Dosey Dough, plus they had one in the oven.  He is also

survived by his elderly father, Pop Tart.




The funeral was held at 350 for about 20 minutes.  If this made you

smile for even a brief second, please rise to the occasion and take time to

pass it on and share that smile with someone else who may be having a crumby

day and kneads a lift.

Looking at the positive side - everything is new again - can watch re-runs, read the same books etc
